docs.snippet: TALK about one-hit wonders. The Danish director Gabriel Axel won a best foreign language film Oscar in 1988 for his wondrous adaptation of Isak Dinesen's marvelous short story, ''Babette's Feast,'' then disappeared off the cinematic radar.    Oh, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: TALK about one-hit wonders. The Danish director Gabriel Axel won a best foreign language film Oscar in 1988 for his wondrous adaptation of Isak Dinesen's marvelous short story, ''Babette's Feast,'' then disappeared off the cinematic radar. Oh, sure, Mr. Axel resurfaced in 1994 with ''Prince of Jutland,'' a three-hour epic based on the Danish Prince Amled, the real-life model for Shakespeare's Hamlet. But the director (who turns 83 this year) had fallen ill during editing and never completed post-production; the rough cut languished for several years, then was released on video by Miramax in 1999. Naturally, it was shorn of nearly half its length -- rendering threadbare even the credible performances of Helen Mirren, Gabriel Byrne and Christian Bale -- and blessed with a new score and a supposedly better title: ''Royal Deceit.''
docs.abstract: Gabriel Axel's 1988 film Babette's Feast is issued in DVD; photo (M)

headline.main: Another Helping of 'Feast' (From a Lean Body of Work)

docs.snippet: They are no longer teammates, but they still share the same goals.    Six members of the 2000 United States Olympic boxing team will make their professional debuts tonight at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. While none of the former Olympians...
docs.lead_paragraph: They are no longer teammates, but they still share the same goals. Six members of the 2000 United States Olympic boxing team will make their professional debuts tonight at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. While none of the former Olympians brought home gold medals from Sydney, Australia, several are expected to become stars as professionals, adding intrigue to the coming out party.
docs.abstract: Six members of US Olympic boxing team make their debuts in bouts at Madison Square Garden; photo (M)

headline.main: Olympians Set for Punchfest at the Garden

docs.snippet: A gallery that sold fake paintings over the Internet will refund $111,000 to 18 bilked customers under a settlement with New York State, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said Wednesday. His office had charged the gallery, the Antique and Design C...
docs.lead_paragraph: A gallery that sold fake paintings over the Internet will refund $111,000 to 18 bilked customers under a settlement with New York State, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said Wednesday. His office had charged the gallery, the Antique and Design Center of New Windsor, N.Y., with offering works with forged signatures of artists like Oscar Bluemner, Milton Avery and Oskar Kokoschka for prices from less than $1,000 to more than $13,000. The gallery owners, Jerry and Jill Schuster, are also to post a $70,000 bond before they can continue to do business in the state and will pay triple damages for any future violations. They did not admit any wrongdoing in agreeing to the settlement. Joseph P. Fried
docs.abstract: Antique and Design Center of New Windsor, NY, gallery that sold fake paintings over Internet, will refund $111,000 to 18 bilked customers under settlement with New York State Attorney General's office (S)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ANTIQUE AND DESIGN CENTER OF NEW WINDSOR

docs.snippet: Ten floors above the bail bondsmen, the sunburned homeless and the wedding ministers-for-hire that dominate downtown, Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas looks out at the gleaming carpet of urban expansion covering the Mojave Desert as far as the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ten floors above the bail bondsmen, the sunburned homeless and the wedding ministers-for-hire that dominate downtown, Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas looks out at the gleaming carpet of urban expansion covering the Mojave Desert as far as the eye can see and utters a civic blasphemy. ''Look at all those gated communities, those big beautiful houses where people don't know their neighbors and never talk to anyone,'' Mr. Goodman says. ''It's nothing but -- I'm not supposed to say this -- sprawl!''
docs.abstract: Las Vegas, Nev, metropolitan area is fastest-growing region in country, with 2000 census showing it adding it about 70,000 people a year; now has population of 1.4 million; troubles abound for city because of such rapid growth, from bad air to choked traffic to diminishing water supply to squalid downtown ignored by big-money casinos that are just beyond city limits on Las Vegas Strip; Mayor Oscar B Goodman says he is concerned about such urban sprawl, and wants core of his city to have 'some culture'--shops, grocery stores, bookstores, apartments, museums and all the other ingredients of a healthy downtown; Goodman photo; US Geological Survey photos show growth of Las Vegas (L)

headline.main: Las Vegas Bet on Growth But Doesn't Love Payoff

docs.snippet: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.    Opera    ''AIDA.'' Opera chat lines have been buzzing with talk that Luciano Pavarotti's ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. Opera ''AIDA.'' Opera chat lines have been buzzing with talk that Luciano Pavarotti's five scheduled performances this month as Radames in Verdi's ''Aida'' at the Met could be his last with the company. It's not hard to understand why, judging from his first performance on Jan. 15. Mr. Pavarotti gets through the role, but just barely, and not without requiring the indulgence and attention of his vocal colleagues and, especially, of James Levine in the orchestra pit. There are still flashes of that Pavarotti sound, but it's sad to watch him struggle with phrases and lumber through the role. Deborah Voigt, who sings the title role splendidly, is making it her own. Olga Borodina is an ideal Amneris. And the baritone Mark Delavan, in his Met debut, is a vocally robust, intelligent and stylish Amonasro. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Only standing-room tickets at $12 and $16 are available (Anthony Tommasini).

docs.lead_paragraph: Richard Steele, the third man in the ring for some of Las Vegas's most memorable fights, says he will not referee again. The 57-year-old Steele said Saturday's fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Diego Corrales was the last one of his career.
docs.abstract: Boxing referee Richard Steele announces retirement (S)

headline.main: Referee Decides To Stop His Career

docs.snippet: The London Stock Exchange confirmed the appointment of Clara Furse as its chief executive and said it was giving greater weight to independent directors by reaching out to a broader pool of business executives. The 200-year-old institution named O...
docs.lead_paragraph: The London Stock Exchange confirmed the appointment of Clara Furse as its chief executive and said it was giving greater weight to independent directors by reaching out to a broader pool of business executives. The 200-year-old institution named Oscar Fanjul, chairman of Hydroelectrica del Cantabrico; Nigel Stapleton, chairman of Veronis Suhler; Robert Webb, a legal executive at British Airways; and Janet Cohen, advisory director at HSBC, to replace board members from financial institutions including Goldman, Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)
docs.abstract: London Stock Exchange confirms appointment of Clara Furse as its chief executive and says it is giving greater weight to independent directors by reaching out to broader pool of business executives; names Oscar Fanjul, Nigel Stapleton, Robert Webb and Janet Cohen to replace board members from financial institutions (S)

docs.snippet: ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' is an elegant opera. By the time he wrote it, Verdi was able with ease to turn a rather ordinary libretto -- with your standard Gypsy fortune teller, doomed passion and conspiracy to murder -- into an opera filled with mel...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' is an elegant opera. By the time he wrote it, Verdi was able with ease to turn a rather ordinary libretto -- with your standard Gypsy fortune teller, doomed passion and conspiracy to murder -- into an opera filled with melody and sparkling ensembles. ''Ballo'' exudes the light-hearted urbanity of its protagonist, King Gustav, a counterpart of the Duke of Mantua in ''Rigoletto'' without the amorality. The Met's revival of Piero Faggioni's 1990 production, which had its season premiere on Monday night, is not an elegant revival. It stakes out the contours of the opera and achieves passages of real emotion and drama. But in place of elegant precision it has a kind of bluntness. It's like a lump of rock shot with a few veins of gold.
docs.abstract: Anne Midgette reviews season's premiere of Metropolitan Opera production of Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera; Placido Domingo is in pit; photo (M)

headline.main: A 'Ballo' Returns, Drama Unmasked, Under Domingo

docs.snippet: And now this urgent bulletin for theatrical stargazers: Hedda Gabler has landed on earth.    You might even say that Ibsen's malevolent modern woman, usually found in some remote Valhalla of stately neurosis, has moved in next door. She can be see...
docs.lead_paragraph: And now this urgent bulletin for theatrical stargazers: Hedda Gabler has landed on earth. You might even say that Ibsen's malevolent modern woman, usually found in some remote Valhalla of stately neurosis, has moved in next door. She can be seen at close quarters now, and she turns out to be an alarmingly real person. Seldom has she seemed so accessible, so vulnerable and -- make no mistake -- so dangerous.
docs.abstract: Ben Brantley reviews Boston's Huntington Theater Co production of Henrik Ibsen's Hedda Gabler, directed by Nicholas Martin; Kate Burton stars; photo (M)

headline.main: The Tortured Trophy Wife Who Lives Next Door

docs.snippet: The Gillette Company turned yesterday to a man who had invigorated the sale of lunch meats and cookies at Nabisco and Kraft in hopes that he might find a better way to sell razors and batteries.    James M. Kilts, who turned around Nabisco Holding...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Gillette Company turned yesterday to a man who had invigorated the sale of lunch meats and cookies at Nabisco and Kraft in hopes that he might find a better way to sell razors and batteries. James M. Kilts, who turned around Nabisco Holdings in his three years there, was hired as the chairman and chief executive of Gillette, effective Feb. 12. He replaces Michael C. Hawley, who served only 18 months before the board voted to ask for his removal. Mr. Kilts will be the second chief executive in Gillette's 100-year history appointed from outside the company. The last outsider, Henry Gaisman, was appointed in 1931.
docs.abstract: James M Kilts, former executive at Nabisco Holdings, is named chairman and chief executive of Gillette Co, replacing Michael C Hawley (M)

headline.main: Gillette Chooses a New Chief, A Veteran of the Cookie Wars
